publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-596.1 Cathy Jamieson: Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices—As an amendment to motion (S1M-596) in the name of Mr Adam Ingram, Delete all after "do not live near a bank" and insert "welcomes the recent announcement that people will be able to continue to receive benefits in cash at post offices before, and after, the introduction of the ACT facilities; recognises the valuable role played by sub-post offices, particularly in rural areas and in areas of urban deprivation, and believes that the Scottish Executive should continue to make representations to the relevant agencies to ensure the continuance and future development of post offices in Scotland."
S1M-596.1 Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices (lodged on 3 March 2000) Helen Eadie*, Rhoda Grant*
S1M-596.1 Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices (lodged on 3 March 2000) Trish Godman*
S1M-596.1 Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices (lodged on 3 March 2000) Margaret Jamieson*
S1M-596.1 Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices (lodged on 3 March 2000) Cathy Peattie*

S1M-596.1 Cathy Jamieson: Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices—As an amendment to motion (S1M-596) in the name of Mr Adam Ingram, Delete all after "do not live near a bank" and insert "welcomes the recent announcement that people will be able to continue to receive benefits in cash at post offices before, and after, the introduction of the ACT facilities; recognises the valuable role played by sub-post offices, particularly in rural areas and in areas of urban deprivation, and believes that the Scottish Executive should continue to make representations to the relevant agencies to ensure the continuance and future development of post offices in Scotland." Supported by: Helen Eadie, Rhoda Grant, Trish Godman, Margaret Jamieson, Cathy Peattie

S1M-596.1 Cathy Jamieson: Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices—As an amendment to motion (S1M-596) in the name of Mr Adam Ingram, Delete all after "do not live near a bank" and insert "welcomes the recent announcement that people will be able to continue to receive benefits in cash at post offices before, and after, the introduction of the ACT facilities; recognises the valuable role played by sub-post offices, particularly in rural areas and in areas of urban deprivation, and believes that the Scottish Executive should continue to make representations to the relevant agencies to ensure the continuance and future development of post offices in Scotland." Supported by: Helen Eadie, Rhoda Grant, Trish Godman, Margaret Jamieson, Cathy Peattie
S1M-596.1 Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices (lodged on 3 March 2000) Dr Richard Simpson*

S1M-596.1 Cathy Jamieson: Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices—As an amendment to motion (S1M-596) in the name of Mr Adam Ingram, Delete all after "do not live near a bank" and insert "welcomes the recent announcement that people will be able to continue to receive benefits in cash at post offices before, and after, the introduction of the ACT facilities; recognises the valuable role played by sub-post offices, particularly in rural areas and in areas of urban deprivation, and believes that the Scottish Executive should continue to make representations to the relevant agencies to ensure the continuance and future development of post offices in Scotland." Supported by: Helen Eadie, Rhoda Grant, Trish Godman, Margaret Jamieson, Cathy Peattie, Dr Richard Simpson

S1M-596.1 Cathy Jamieson: Change in Benefit Payments-Effects on Post Offices—As an amendment to motion (S1M-596) in the name of Mr Adam Ingram, Delete all after "do not live near a bank" and insert "welcomes the recent announcement that people will be able to continue to receive benefits in cash at post offices before, and after, the introduction of the ACT facilities; recognises the valuable role played by sub-post offices, particularly in rural areas and in areas of urban deprivation, and believes that the Scottish Executive should continue to make representations to the relevant agencies to ensure the continuance and future development of post offices in Scotland." Supported by: Helen Eadie, Rhoda Grant, Trish Godman, Margaret Jamieson, Cathy Peattie, Dr Richard Simpson
